meta.article_title: May 27, 2024 - What to Do in the First Game

what_to_do_in_the_first_game.probleme: Unclear priorities and adjustments in the first game of a match.

debutant: Force your game early by serving/receiving and rallying to set up your main strengths.
Adjust quickly to any unorthodox strokes or equipment so you are comfortable before game two.
intermediaire: If slow to start, use tactical disruptors to win the first game (e.g., heavy push, slow spinny loop, angled block) while your full game warms up.
avance: Use the first game to learn the blueprint to win the match, even if you lose that game, rather than relying on luck.

erreurs_a_eviter: Entering game two still uncomfortable with an opponent’s style or surface.
Relying on lucky points without identifying winning tactics.

meta.article_title: May 20, 2024 - Smother the Table When Blocking

smother_the_table_when_blocking.probleme: Ineffective blocks and late contact on wide balls.
smother_the_table_when_blocking.diagnostic: Players move only sideways, arrive late, take the ball too far out, and often twist the body on wide backhands.
causes_communes: Standing too far from the table when blocking.
Pure lateral movement without cutting off the angle.
Rotating the body and facing sideways on wide backhands.

debutant: : stay close and think quick, compact blocks.
intermediaire: Move both sideways and forward to cut off wide balls before they bounce out; maintain balanced posture on backhand without over-rotating.
avance: Use early timing and firm blocks to deny angles while recovering to neutral after contact.

erreurs_a_eviter: Only drifting sideways on wide balls.
Taking contact late and producing weak, floaty blocks.

meta.article_title: May 13, 2024 - Focus on Placement to Win and Increase Consistency

focus_on_placement_to_win_and_increase_c.probleme: Vague targeting reduces both effectiveness and consistency.
focus_on_placement_to_win_and_increase_c.diagnostic: Players aim at broad areas (FH/BH/middle) instead of specific spots.
causes_communes: rather than to a precise point.

debutant: Before each shot, choose a specific spot; the middle target is the opponent’s playing elbow.
intermediaire: Play to extreme placements (very wide or precisely to middle) to exploit weaknesses and to improve precision.
avance: Automate targeting so the subconscious selects and executes precise placements during fast rallies.

erreurs_a_eviter: Aiming vaguely and trusting chance to find corners.
Assuming conscious selection is feasible in high-speed rallies (it becomes subconscious with habit).

meta.article_title: May 6, 2024 - Shadow Practice for Fitness and Improvement

shadow_practice_for_fitness_and_improvem.probleme: General conditioning without sport-specific footwork development.
shadow_practice_for_fitness_and_improvem.diagnostic: Running builds fitness but not table-tennis-specific movement patterns.

debutant: Replace a ~15-minute run with a ~15-minute shadow footwork routine in an open space.
intermediaire: Create intervals (e.g., 60s work, 10s rest) for drills: FH-FH lateral; BH-BH lateral; FH-BH corner to corner; BH-FH-FH sequence; three-point FH; in-out footwork.
Repeat the circuit 2–3 times per session.
avance: Adjust durations to age/fitness; emphasize correct stance, recovery, and stroke simulation during each pattern.

exercices_complementaires.description: Perform six drills (listed in solutions) for 60 seconds each with 10 seconds rest; complete 2–3 circuits.
exercices_complementaires.duree: 14–21 minutes per session (as stated in source).

erreurs_a_eviter: Treating conditioning as separate from movement skill; omit footwork specificity.

meta.article_title: April 29, 2024 - Forehand or Backhand Receive in Doubles

forehand_or_backhand_receive_in_doubles.probleme: Choosing forehand vs backhand receive options in doubles.
forehand_or_backhand_receive_in_doubles.diagnostic: Backhand banana flip made backhand receive common; choice depends on skills and partner dynamics.

debutant: Option 1—Forehand receive: positions you to forehand loop long serves; vs short serves, forehand flip or push.
Option 2—Backhand receive: enables backhand banana or conventional backhand flip; requires being ready to play backhand vs long serves.
intermediaire: Option 3—Hybrid: set up for forehand; step in to backhand receive if serve is short; loop forehand if long. Practice quick long/short judgement.
Choose the receiving side that is your strongest against the server’s typical placements; consider lefty–righty interference.
avance: Attack most deep serves (loop); vary short-serve receives (short/long push, flips). Exploit wide angles to tangle server with partner; drop short against short backspin/no-spin when partner would face a strong third ball.

erreurs_a_eviter: Defaulting to one receive style regardless of strengths or serve types.
Pushing deep too often and exposing partner to attacks.

meta.article_title: April 22, 2024 - Serve or Receive First in Doubles?

serve_or_receive_first_in_doubles.probleme: Deciding whether to serve or receive first in doubles.
serve_or_receive_first_in_doubles.diagnostic: Receiving first often advantageous: early jitters are less costly and you control order of play; order matters especially in game five.

debutant: Prefer to receive first to set the order and to serve under pressure later (e.g., 9-all).
intermediaire: order after the switch at five points in game five and at deuce.
avance: Choose to serve first only if you or partner needs confidence; otherwise plan around order effects in tight endings.

erreurs_a_eviter: Ignoring order-of-play implications in the fifth game.

meta.article_title: April 15, 2024 - How to Play Doubles with a Much Stronger or Weaker Player

how_to_play_doubles_with_a_much_stronger.probleme: Tactics for lopsided doubles teams (one partner much stronger).
how_to_play_doubles_with_a_much_stronger.diagnostic: A smart lopsided team can be favored if the stronger player dominates or controls and the weaker supports without being passive.

debutant: Mindset: weaker player should be confident and play smart; stronger player reassures and keeps tactics simple.
intermediaire: Serving: weaker player prepares short, low serves (backspin/no-spin) toward middle to prevent strong attacks and let partner make first shot.
Rallying: weaker focuses on depth and consistency; end points when truly easy balls appear.
Both partners work to bring their strengths into play via serve/receive patterns.
avance: Stronger player may test deep/tricky serves depending on opponents; adjust if partner cannot finish pop-ups.
Define roles: dominating play (repeated attacks) vs controlling play (safe, set-ups that deny opponent chances).

erreurs_a_eviter: Weaker player serving attackable balls that immediately put team on defense.
Weaker player over-attacking and taking partner out of play.

meta.article_title: April 8, 2024 - Top Ten Things to Remember in Doubles

top_ten_things_to_remember_in_doubles.probleme: Teams neglect core doubles principles (serve/receive coordination, placement, movement, teamwork).

debutant: Signal serves (under table: down=backspin, up=topspin, sideways=sidespin, fist=no-spin; point toward opponents for long).
Serve to set up partner; normally avoid long and too-wide serves; serve low.
Receive to set up partner; often receive to the left to tangle server with partner; attack deep serves.
intermediaire: If stronger with backhand flip/loop, receive backhand more; some set up FH receive but switch to BH on short serves.
Movement: don’t step too far sideways; step back slightly so partner moves in front and then rotate back in.
Place rally shots either back to the striker or away from his partner to create interference; avoid giving easy angles.
avance: Maintain team communication and avoid squabbling; address issues as a unit.

erreurs_a_eviter: Serving long or too wide by default in doubles.
Moving laterally out of position instead of stepping back to give partner room.
